results.title: High fidelity
results.creator_credit: Stephen Frears, Rudd Simmons, Tim Bevan and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: This cult retro-pop-classic based on the book by Nick Hornby takes the audience back to the pop culture of the 80’s. Enter the jaded Rob (John Cusack), owner of Championship Vinyl, a man in his late 30’s whose passion for music and Peter Pan approach to life has caught up with him. When present girlfriend, Laura (Iben Kjejle), leaves him, he names his top 5 most memorable break-ups. The audience is taken on a loop of youth culture as well as being offered a glimpse into the male view of matters of the heart. The film uses Rob’s side-kicks (the “musical moron twins”), Dick and Barry (played by Todd Louiso Jack Black respectively), to help play homage to the music scene, never faltering, the two pastiche’ musical obsession to new heights, peppering the film with their top 5’s and hilarious musical anecdotes and showdowns. With a guest appearance by Bruce Springsteen, the cast is well courted with actors including Tim Robbins, Joan Cusack, Lisa Bonet, Lili Taylor and Catherine Zeta-Jones. Video also includes a 6 minute interview with John Cusack about the making of the film.

results.title: High endeavour
results.creator_credit: Martin Films and British Information Services
results.brief_description: The design, construction and testing of the Avro Vulcan, the world’s first four-jet delta-wing bomber, now playing an important role in Britain’s defence system. An historical introduction includes sequences on the Vulcan’s famous predecessor, the Lancaster, and shows some of its wartime exploits.

results.title: High country children of New Zealand
results.creator_credit: Yvonne MacKay, Dave Gibson and Gibson Film Productions
results.brief_description: Two children - Malcolm and Nerelli Prouting - live with their family on a sheep station in the isolated high country of south New Zealand. This film shows their daily lives from the excitement of mustering high up in the hills to mundane correspondence school work. Filmed on location at Mount Arrowsmith Station, New Zealand.

results.title: High art [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Lisa Cholodenko, Susan A Stover, Jeff Levy-Hinte, Dolly Hall and October Films
results.brief_description: Syd (Radha Mitchell) is a young women with a perfectly nice boyfriend and a perfectly good job working for an up-market photography magazine in New York City. But she is bored and keen for adventure, hoping to achieve more status and celebrity through work. A chance encounter with a legendary underground photographer, Lucy Berliner (Ally Sheedy), enables Syd to move into the exotic fringes of the art world, as well as allowing her to explore her own sexuality and her own desires. But “High Art” is not a New Age film: we watch Syd’s pursuit of Lucy and of fame, and we are asked to confront deeply disturbing questions about the amorality of contemporary relationships and culture. Art may be what all the characters in this film claim to care about, but their real pursuits are status and fame. Only Lucy Berliner, passionate about her photography, seems capable of committing herself to a notion of art that is not simply reducible to commerce. But Lucy’s passion comes at a cost: life on the fringe, the dangers of drugs, and the continual question of where the rent money is going to come from. The final moments of this film, in which Syd faces what is really of value in the world of “high art”, are shattering. Music by Shudder to Think. Sheedy and Mitchell are outstanding. Winner of the Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: High art
results.creator_credit: North Richmond Community Health Centre, Michael Buckley and Julie Shiels
results.brief_description:
The North Richmond Community Health Centre has an extensive Arts and Culture program which invites community members to describe and celebrate their culture and ideas. The HIGH ART CDROM is a documentation of more than 14 projects and uses video, animations, interviews and graphics to exhibit the work.

HIGH ART also expores the more complex elements of cultural diversity by asking a number of questions including, “What is a community and who belongs to it? Is it where they live or how they live? Can art make you healthy? If it does, is it art or is it therapy? Do migrants get a fair go in the media? What does multiculturalism mean at the end of the 20th century

Also included in the CDROM is a series of essays that describe and evaluate the relationship between art and health.

results.title: High Arctic: life on the land
results.creator_credit: Dalton Muir, Hugh O'Connor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An ecological study, in full colour, of plant and animal life on the Queen Elizabeth Islands in the Canadian Arctic, and of the life cycles that are the law of nature even in these frozen wastelands. Animals such as the musk-ox, lemming and arctic hare, and various forms of plant life, are seen as part of an evolution that began in pre-history. Commentary: Strowan Robertson
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dalton Muir, Hugh O’Connor, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: High anxiety (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mel Brooks, Crossbow Films and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: ‘High Anxiety’ is a parody of, and a dedication to, the cinema of Alfred Hitchcock. Using the simple plot of a psychiatrist with a fear of heights who arrives to take up a top post as head of the Institute for the Very, Very Nervous, Mel Brooks uses a gamut of scatological, Freudian and slap-stick jokes to create hilarious parodies of famous scenes in ‘The Birds’, ‘Psycho’, ‘Vertigo’ et. al. Cast includes Cloris Leachman, Madeline Kahn and Harvey Korman. The script was co-written by Barry Levinson.

results.title: High and low = Tengoku to jigoku [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Ryuzo Kikushima, Tomoyuki Tanaka and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: In the first half a kidnapping takes place and a ransom is negotiated; the second half deals with the manhunt for the kidnapper. The Japanese title - Heaven and Hell - directly suggests exact opposites and more clearly encapsulates the theme. It begins in ‘Heaven’ - the apartment high over the city - and ends in ‘Hell’ - the alleyways of Yokohama. The first half is superficially theatrical in its refusal of conventional editing strategies but actually is notable for its subtle dramatic geometry involving permutations of position and composition afforded by the Scope screen. Multiple cameras were used to film long takes. The film suddenly opens out into an action-packed chase. Based on the novel “King’s Ransom” by Ed McBain. Cast includes Toshiro Mifune, Tatsuya Nakadai, Kyoko Kagawa. In Japanese with English subtitles.
